awd_titl_txt: CRI: II-NEW: HoloCamera: An Immersive Gigapixel Cyberinstrument for Creating Precision Virtual Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
Title: HoloCamera: An Immersive Gigapixel Cyberinstrument for Creating Precision Virtual Environments 

Virtual worlds need high-quality realism for effective use. The HoloCamera will meet these needs.  Using several cameras and a computer cluster it will directly create dynamic virtual worlds. Users will be able to freely move about and observe these virtual worlds as if they were actually present there.

The HoloCamera will advance the state of the art in light field capture and rendering, high-performance computing, and embedded signal processing. The facility will aid medical education and training, interactive imitation learning for robots, and capturing fluent sign-language use in native signers. Virtual and augmented reality offer exciting ways to educate students, particularly those from underrepresented groups in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) disciplines.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview: We have designed and developed the HoloCamera, a revolutionary facility comprised of a unique, spatially enveloping array of cameras and a computational cluster to facilitate acquisition, processing, and generation of precision virtual environments for scientific exploration, knowledge discovery, training, and education. We have developed new computational techniques that use a minimally calibrated ensemble of cameras to reproduce dynamic 3D scenes, with the goal of allowing a user to freely navigate and observe the environment as if they are actually present there. This effort presents a historic opportunity for a transformative leap forward in creation of dynamic virtual worlds directly from real-world scenarios. The HoloCamera will facilitate computing research in computing areas including graphics, virtual environments, high-performance computing, signal processing, assistive and rehabilitative technologies, and robotics, as well as visually augmented medical applications at the University of Maryland and beyond.

Intellectual Merit Outcomes: Currently, most VR and AR environments are laboriously constructed by a designer. This works well for 3D computer games with pre-determined, artistically created, virtual 3D content. However, for cinematic-quality realism for applications in telepresence, medical training, and education, we need to reconstruct reality rapidly and faithfully, with accurate mathematical modeling and significantly higher precision. In response to that need, we have built a high precision cyberinstrument that can capture true-to-life realistic immersive environments. Specialized camera mounts allow us to maximize capture space, and our modular camera setup can capture synchronized frames at up to 30 FPS. We utilize a state-of-the-art neural network, trained specifically for background subtraction on 4K video frames, to extract foreground segments from our raw footage. The neural network processes the frames in two stages. It first extracts the rough contour of foreground content and highlights border pixel regions; then the border pixel regions are further refined in the second stage to extract high-resolution details such as strands of hair. We have further processed the extracted foreground mask into an intermediate 3D mesh and have been able to achieve a significant size reduction on transmissible geometry data, while maintaining consistent levels of detail. We have also developed a custom-built streaming software to facilitate the process of manually focusing the HoloCamera?s lenses. Finally, we have designed and constructed a custom overhead camera array solution to provide a birds-eye-view for the HoloCamera, bringing the total number of cameras to 300.

Broader Impact Outcomes: Our HoloCamera advances the state of the art in light field rendering, live scene reconstruction, high-performance computing, and embedded signal and information processing; potential applications are significant. This facility brings us closer to true and effective telepresence and remote participation through its ability to capture and convey nuanced facial microexpressions, body language, and person-to-person engagement. We are collaborating with the University of Maryland R Adams Cowley Shock Trauma Center (immersive anatomy education modules), the School of Medicine?s Center for Integrative Medicine (VR-enhanced medical student education) and the School of Nursing (VR patient-care training modules for emergency scenarios). The HoloCamera is a key facility for our new NSF Industry-University Cooperative Research Center, the Center for Medical Innovations in Extended Reality (MIXR). MIXR builds the scientific foundations for designing and assessing extended-reality applications in medicine. Collaborating with our industry partners and regulatory scientists, the University of Maryland, College Park, along with partner sites at University of Maryland, Baltimore and University of Michigan, are exploring the use of XR to improve public health and healthcare outcomes across education and simulation, clinical care delivery, and applying data science and machine learning to improve diagnosis and therapeutics.
